thread.title: North Texas' Ironman World Championship Participants: The Legacy Winners
thread.title_full: North Texas' Ironman World Championship Participants: The Legacy Winners | Dallas Morning News

author: Debbie Fetterman
title: North Texas' Ironman World Championship Participants: The Legacy Winners
text:
Dallas' Jim Linck and Phillip Jones consistently raced Ironman events for years.
Their dedication to the brand paid off. They earned a slot at Kona this year through its Legacy Program.
To be eligible, they had to complete at least 12 full Ironman-branded events, have never started the Ironman World Championships and have completed at least one Ironman event in 2013, 2014 and 2015.
They've among 100 Ironman Legacy winners this year including 64 Americans, 18 Australians, seven Canadians and four athletes from Great Britain. Other Legacy winners are from Singapore, Germany, New Zealand, Panama, Brazil and France.
Linck, 50, holds the Distinguished Chair in Finance at the SMU Cox School of Business. He played sports through high school and started running for health around age 40. In 2009, his identical twin brother convinced him into do an endurance triathlons with him.
He said he "got hooked after that." Kona will be his 19 th full Ironman.
For Jones, 53, the president and CEO of the Dallas Convention & Visitors Bureau, Kona will be his 15th Ironman race. Racing in Hawaii will be his is more than the completion of a long-term goal for him.
He's also using it as an opportunity to raise awareness and funds for a personal cause: to eradicate Lyme Disease. Jones' 25-year-old son contracted the debilitating disease from a tick bite four years ago.
